relation: Hide context information in task status
Hide context information in task status
Block fork when RSS limit is exceeded
Allow context to create new contexts
pageTitle: Difference between revisions of "Capabilities and Flags" - Linux-VServer
textBeforeTable: The set of available context capabilities is specific to Linux-VServer and applied to all processes contained within a context. Below is a list of capabilities currently available in 2.1.1 and above. Context capabilities (ccaps) Slightly different meaning in legacy X Unsupported U One time capability/flag O Only supported with legacy enabled L Internal use only I Description Tag The tag column may contain one or more of the following tags: Special capability/flags codes Description  Description of capability/flag effects Special capability/flag code to denote special behaviour, legacy usage and others (see below) Tag  Human readable identifier used in userspace utilities Name  The bit number in hexadecimal notation Mask  The bit number to enable the capability/flag Bit  Below is a list of capabilities and flags used for contexts and processes within. The tables contain the following information: List of capabilities/flags The difference between the context flags and the context capabilities is more an abstract logical separation than a functional one, because they are handled very similar. Consider the
textAfterTable: 0x01000000 HIDE_MOUNT Hide entries in /proc/$pid/mounts 29 0x02000000 HIDE_NETIF Hide foreign network interfaces 30 0x04000000 HIDE_VINFO Hide context information in task status 32 0x0001<<32 STATE_SETUP IO Enable setup state 33 0x0002<<32 STATE_INIT IO Enable init state 34 0x0004<<32 STATE_ADMIN O Enable admin state 36 0x0010<<32 SC_HELPER I Enable state change helper 37 0x0020<<32 REBOOT_KILL Kill all processes on reboot(2) 38 0x0040<<32 PERSISTENT Make context persistent 48 0x0001<<48 FORK_RSS Block fork when RSS limit is exceeded 49 0x0002<<48 PROLIFIC Allow context to
